Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports participants in the 2017 Maine-Québec Number Theory Conference, to take place on October 14-15, 2017 at the University of Maine. This is an annual conference, held at Laval University in Québec in even years and at the University of Maine in odd years. By providing a forum for number theorists from New England, Québec, and beyond, it promotes interaction and collaboration between Canadian and American mathematics researchers.

The conference features approximately 35 lectures addressing recent progress in different areas of number theory. The small scale of the meeting (with roughly 65 attendees) makes this a good opportunity for graduate students and young mathematicians to interact with leading researchers. This award also provides some travel support for U.S.-based participants to attend the 2018 meeting in Québec. The conference website has more information, including participant lists and programs from recent years:
http://www.math.umaine.edu/numbertheory/mainequebec.html

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2017 Maine/Quebec Number Theory Conference took place on October 14-15, 2017 at the University of Maine. In all there were 51 lectures on many topics in number theory, including plenary talks by John Friedlander (University of Toronto) and Henryk Iwaniec (Rutgers University). There were 85 participants, including 30 graduate students and 4 undergraduates. The full program and participant list can be viewed on the conference website.

The grant was used to provide travel and lodging for 71 conference participants in 2017 who came from outside the Orono area, as well as catering and supplies. A very small portion of the grant remained, and this was used to help with the travel costs of some of the University of Maine faculty to attend the 2018 Quebec/Maine number theory conference, which was held at Laval University on October 6-7, 2018.

Number theory, the study of the integers and related structures, is one of the oldest branches in mathematics, and remains very active.  This conference provided a forum for researchers in number theory from New England and Quebec to meet, present and discuss their work, and initiate collaboration for future research progress. The small scale of this annual meeting makes it a good opportunity for graduate students and young mathematicians to interact with more senior researchers.
